Indeed, 80 years is but a blink. The schisms reflect the fundamental boundaries of trust for peoples throughout the region, but even that implies a false indication of unity. Tribalism is much older than any form of Islam, or even Christianity, and has been troublesome for successive conquerors and leaders for more than two millennia. Grievances run deep and outlast generations. Geopolitical boundaries mean little - where they bisect a tribe or sect, border populations are fungible.

When you ask people to whom faith is more important than personal survival what they need, they will always ask for guns. What they need most is education sufficient to build some understanding and empathy that transcends their parochial sectarian and tribal world. Violence is not a shortcut to peace, unless we want to favor one sect over the others to the most extreme finality. I hope that such an idea would be repugnant to most Americans.

When I read Muhammad Asad's autobiographical account of his life, "Road to Mecca," from his Jewish birth as Leopold Weiss in the Ukraine on July 2, 1900 through 1932, I was struck by his accounts of the nations of what we know as "the Middle East."

Struck because so much of what he wrote of 80 some years ago is so little affected, other than superficially, relative to what we recognize about those nations fundamentally now.

Sunnis, Shias, Alawites, Kurds... the sectarian factions and disagreements of his time underlaid the shared Islam just like the tectonic fracture in East Africa does segments of that continent.

And just as that rift pulls and pushes those factions further apart, so do the ancient, apparently irreconcilable tribes and partitions of the Middle East.

I'm with you François, and have an additional point/question.

I was vegetarian for about three months many years ago. Then in a fit of absent-mindedness, I bought a piece of red meat, and figured I might as well cook it. The next morning -- a crisp Boston winter morning -- I felt incredibly warm, more so than in months, like a had a new furnace in me.

I talked with a friend a few years later, who was vegetarian where she was raised in the south, but ate meat in Boston "because it's cold".

Is meat "good" for us in cold weather -- even if not healthy in the long run? I have heard enough anecdotes, and felt in strongly enough myself, to believe so. Can anyone point me to any more rigorous studies?

Sounds like you've never had a meal where the main dish is rice and lentils or rice and beans, or even a spaghetti dinner without meatballs. Believe me, there's no "deep hunger" after that. Crunch, crunch? Remember, rice, lentils, beans, wheat, and tomatos are indeed plants.
You really need to find some good vegan recipes.  There are many sources on the web.

As a broad rule of thumb, I try not to eat animal products from CAFOs or other cruel, over-industrialized sources.  So I eat more vegetarian at restaurants and what I want when I cook at home, because I buy free-range, organic and pasture-raised animal products.  I have tried to eat vegan and always reach a point after a few days of a deeper hunger that plants alone  just cannot satisfy.  I love veggies, but ironically have found that eating them too exclusively turns eating into a dreaded moral chore, endless variations on kale/spinach/chard/bok choy and garlic.  Crunch, crunch, crunch.  Crunch, crunch, crunch....

Yes, relegation won't work in this country because the brave captains of industry that own team love to talk a good game about competition and capitalism, but then can't walk it. American sport for the owners is as socialist as it gets (except, of course for the players, who get tossed away when they're no longer useful. Or fans, who have to pay what the market will bear). Drafts, salary caps, rules to ensure parity, etc.

Relegation is good because while some teams are treated harshly by it, most teams who go down deserve it. It's good because of it's flip side, promotion, which rewards teams that work hard to rise up the leagues. It makes end of season games exciting at both ends of the standings - in fact, the relegation battle is often more interesting than the championship.

Another reason owners don't like it: they can't shake the incoming owners down for entry fees.
